I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), policy and 
advisory technical assistance (TA) for Strengthening Technical and Vocational Education and 
Training for Development of Priority Sectors in Shaanxi Province1 was included in the 2012 
nonlending program of the Asian  Development  Bank (ADB)  in the PRC country operations 
business plan, 2012–2014. ADB undertook TA reconnaissance2 in April 2011 and a consultation 
mission in November 2011. Agreement was reached with the government regarding the TA’s 
impact, outcome, outputs, costs and financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms 
of reference for consulting services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  PRC’s  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015  outlines  development  goals  in  the 
context of a transition from export-oriented to domestic demand-driven growth. This transition, 
taking  place  amid  the  country’s  ongoing  urbanization  process,  has  generated  enormous 
demand for skilled workers. To support this development, the government has prioritized the 
development of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) to help the country 
cultivate and maintain a competitive labor force. 
 
3.  Through continued investment, the PRC has developed a comprehensive TVET system, 
including a number of demonstration schools that are able to adjust to the demands of the 
market. However, the system faces several challenges in ensuring that TVET services keep 
pace with the economic transformation. One major challenge is increasing the efficiency and 
responsiveness of the TVET system. Unlike general education, TVET involves a wide range of 
stakeholders who provide policy directions to ensure that the demand for skills is satisfied. As 
the PRC’s economy continues to grow, the effectiveness of the TVET system will be measured 
by how well it boosts employability and work competency. To achieve this goal, the government 
is making efforts to strengthen the link between the labor market and TVET, including the 
emergence across the country of various partnership models between schools and enterprises. 
One example of this is vocational education groups (VEGs), which comprise TVET schools and 
industrial associations and enterprises in a specialized field. VEGs provide an institutionalized 
platform to strengthen the link between the supply of and demand for skilled labor. 
 
4.  Shaanxi is one of the 12 less-developed provinces and autonomous regions supported 
by the government under its National Strategy for Development of the West. The provincial 
economy has historically been dominated by agriculture, but under the National Strategy for 
Development of the West, Shaanxi has rapidly industrialized and urbanized since the 1980s. At 
the end of 2010, the provincial gross domestic product was about CNY1,002 billion, ranking 
14th among the provinces and autonomous regions in the PRC. Between the end of 1999 and 
the end of 2010, the contribution to the provincial gross domestic product from the primary 
sector decreased from 18.0% to 9.7%, the contribution from the secondary sector increased 
from 43.1% to 51.9%, and the contribution from the tertiary sector dropped from 38.9% to 38.5%. 
The  provincial  development  strategy  prioritizes  the  agriculture,  energy,  manufacturing,  and 
service sectors to underpin the province’s long-term development. Skills in these four sectors 
urgently need to be upgraded to support economic development under the Twelfth Five-Year 
Plan. Additionally, the use of high-technology, sophisticated business operations and complex

modern production systems require a high-quality workforce. Human resource development 
must adapt and respond to the rapid changes that are taking place across business sectors.   
 
5.  Since the early 1990s, Shaanxi has rapidly become urbanized as millions of migrant 
farmers have moved to cities and towns to take nonagricultural jobs. At the end of 2010, the 
province had an urbanization level of 46.5%, compared with 26.84% in 1998. Urbanization in 
Shaanxi is expected to reach 57% by the end of 2015, with the addition of about 6 million 
people to the urban population between 2011 and 2015. Under the Twelfth Five-Year Plan, the 
province will need to produce an additional 740,000 highly skilled workers. 
 
6.  TVET services in Shaanxi are generally provided by multidisciplinary schools, which 
have strong administrative links with different government agencies, including those inherited 
from the planned economy. In 2008, the Shaanxi provincial government introduced reforms by 
setting up VEGs along specialized professional lines to consolidate TVET resources and to 
foster demand-driven TVET service provision. Typical VEGs comprise schools that share the 
same professional domain, similar enterprises, and similar industrial associations. VEGs have 
two basic functions: (i) bring together industries and TVET schools; and (ii) link less-developed 
TVET schools with well-established ones to consolidate TVET resources, with the goal of 
improving the provision of services. With the support of the provincial government, Shaanxi is 
piloting  15  VEGs,  including  Yangling  modern  agriculture  VEGs,  Shaanxi  energy  VEGs,  a 
Shaanxi manufacturing VEG, and a Shaanxi service sector VEG. 
 
7.  Although  provincial  regulations  supported  the  establishment  of  VEGs,  detailed 
guidelines  have  not  yet  been  developed.  As  a  result, the  activities  of  VEGs  are  currently 
constrained and VEGs are being underutilized. The provincial government expects VEGs to 
play an important role in bridging supply and demand in the labor market and strengthening 
links  between  developed  and  less-developed  schools  for  quality  improvement.  Developed 
schools  should  negotiate  the  development  of  innovative  school–enterprise  partnerships  to 
respond to enterprise labor demand, while less-developed schools could learn from developed 
schools and maximize the role of existing VEGs toward ensuring TVET improvement in Shaanxi 
Province. 
 
8.  Through the TA, the government requests that ADB conduct an in-depth study on VEGs 
in Shaanxi’s four priority sectors, and make suggestions on how these VEGs can be improved. 
The TA will help the provincial government make recommendations to improve TVET services 
using these newly strengthened VEGs to support the development of its priority sectors. The TA 
will  also  provide  guidance  on  how  school–enterprise  and  school–school  partnerships  can 
develop and implement a demand-based curriculum based on labor market analysis supported 
by relevant provincial departments, including education, human resources, and social security. 
The results of the TA will be shared with key stakeholders at the TA final workshop. The 
experience of Shaanxi is expected to have a strong demonstration potential for other inland 
provinces and autonomous regions that face similar development challenges as a result of 
ongoing urbanization. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be a stronger and more competitive labor market in the priority 
sectors in Shaanxi Province. The outcome of the TA will be a comprehensive analysis of and

3 
recommendations for how to strengthen VEGs, including the advancement of TVET school–
enterprise partnerships and TVET school–school partnerships in the priority sectors. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will produce two outputs: (i) strategies and policy guidelines to improve VEGs, 
and (ii) development of a demand-driven curriculum for one subject in each of the four priority 
sectors, on a pilot basis. These will be achieved through (i) an analysis of the labor market, 
human  resources  needs,  and  the  skills  qualifications  framework  in  priority  sectors;  (ii)  an 
analysis  of  current  VEGs  (school–enterprise  and  school–school  partnerships);  (iii) 
recommendations on incentive mechanisms to promote the participation of enterprises in TVET 
development; (iv) suggestions to improve a labor projection model in the four priority sectors; (v) 
recommendations to improve the skills qualifications framework; and (vi) development of the 
curriculum framework, curriculum, and the implementation guidelines of one selected subject for 
each of the four priority sectors. The provincial government has key systems (e.g., qualifications 
framework) and tools (e.g., labor projection models) to conduct these activities. The TA will use 
existing resources to produce outputs and prepare recommendations. The two outputs will be 
presented in the form of a TA technical report. In addition, a policy note that summarizes key 
policy recommendations to improve VEGs will be prepared for policy makers. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The government has requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).  
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of in-kind contributions, including 
counterpart staff, a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access, and 
materials such as documents and data. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The Shaanxi Department of Finance (SDOF) will be the executing agency for the TA, 
and will be responsible for the overall execution and coordination of TA activities. SDOF has 
rich experience in implementing international projects, including ADB loan and TA projects. The 
Shaanxi Department of Education (SDOE) will be the implementing agency. Under the guidance 
of SDOF, SDOE will be responsible for the day-to-day TA implementation. SDOE will work 
closely with consultants to ensure that TA policy recommendations will be feasible for Shaanxi 
Province. Under the supervision and guidance of SDOE, a project implementation office will be 
established  at  the  Provincial  Institute  of  Education  Science  to  provide  assistance  in 
implementing TA activities. In addition, the provincial government will establish an interagency 
project steering committee to provide overall guidance and support for TA implementation. The 
steering  committee  will  be chaired by  a  deputy  governor  of  Shaanxi  Province.  Committee 
members  will  include  representatives  from  SDOF,  SDOE,  the  Shaanxi  Development  and 
Reform Commission, the Shaanxi Department of Human Resources and Social Security, the 
Shaanxi Department of Agriculture, and the Shaanxi Commission for Industry and Information 
Technology. 
 
13.  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). An advance payment facility 
will  be  established  at  the  implementing  agency  for  expenses  on  workshops,  surveys, 
international study visits, and equipment. Procurement of equipment will be done in accordance 
with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Purchased

4   
equipment will be turned over to the executing agency upon completion of the TA activities. The 
government will provide an in-kind contribution to cover remuneration of counterpart staff, office 
space, utilities, and in-city transportation in Xian. 
 
14.  The TA consultants will be engaged by ADB through a firm in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and based on the 
quality of the proposal (90%) and the cost (10%) of the services to be provided (under the 
quality- and cost-based selection method), using a simplified technical proposal. The 90:10 
weighting is considered appropriate because the TA is expected to have a strong impact on the 
development of future TVET policies in Shaanxi Province, and therefore requires high-quality 
technical  inputs.  The  TA  will  provide  a  total  of  35  person-months  of  consulting  services, 
including 4 person-months of international and 31 person-months of national consultant inputs. 
The TA will be implemented over 12 months, from September 2012 to August 2013. The outline 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. Major project activities will be regularly 
monitored and reported to SDOF and ADB administrative missions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening Technical and Vocational 
Education and Training for Development of Priority Sectors in Shaanxi Province, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of eight consultants for a total of 
35 person-months, consisting of one international consultant (4 person-months) and seven 
national consultants (31 person-months), over a period of 12 months during TA implementation.  
 
2.  To promote full acceptance of the TA outcome, the consultants will perform their tasks in 
close  consultation  with  the  executing  agency,  the  Shaanxi  Department  of  Finance;  the 
implementing agency, the Shaanxi Department of Education; and other responsible provincial 
and local government departments and agencies. The consultants will need to have guidance 
from and consultations with the Provincial Institute of Education Science on the implementation 
of TA activities.  
 
3.  The TA will produce two outputs. The first output is a set of strategies and policy 
guidelines to improve vocational education groups (VEGs) in four priority sectors. The output 
includes (i) an analysis of the labor market, human resources needs, and the skills qualifications 
framework of priority sectors; (ii) an analysis of current VEGs (school–enterprise and school–
school  partnerships);  (iii)  recommendations  on  incentive  mechanisms  to  promote  the 
participation of enterprises in TVET development; (iv) suggestions to improve a labor projection 
model  in the four  priority  sectors; (v)  recommendations to  improve the  skills qualifications 
framework;  and  (vi)  development  of  the  curriculum  framework,  curriculum,  and  the 
implementation guidelines of one selected subject for each of the four priority sectors. The 
second output is development of a demand-driven curriculum for one subject in each of the four 
priority sectors, on a pilot basis. Based on the analysis of the labor market, human resources 
needs, and skills mapping (category and level) in the priority sectors, a curriculum framework, 
curriculum, and its implementation guidelines for each priority sector will be developed. The two 
outputs will be presented in the form of a TA technical report. In addition, a policy note that 
summarizes key policy recommendations to improve VEGs will be prepared for policy makers.  
 
4.  All consultants should be familiar with Shaanxi Province, including its socioeconomic 
context. Work experience in the province is preferable. 
 
5.  The  consulting  team  will  arrange  all  the  necessary  translations  needed  for  the  TA 
activities. Key deliverables are (i) an inception report, (ii) a field survey design and its tools, (iii) 
a midterm review report, (iv) a draft final technical report and a policy note, and (v) a final 
technical report and a policy note. 
 
A.  Team Leader and Expert on Vocational Education Groups (national, 11 person-
months) 
 
6.  The team leader should have at least 10 years of experience in TVET development.  His 
or  her  expertise  and  experiences  must  include  school–enterprise  partnership  for  TVET 
development.  The team leader must have a good command of English.  He or she will perform 
the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Prepare all the required reports in English and Chinese: (a) an inception report, 
(b) a field survey design and its tools, (c) a midterm review report, (d) a draft final 
technical report and policy note, and (e) a final technical report and policy note. 
All reports must be prepared reflecting all consultants’ inputs and activities, meet 
international standards quality, and submitted to the Asian Development Bank, 
and the executing and implementing agencies, on time.

(ii)  Ensure all inputs are locally adaptable and feasible in close consultation with the 
executing and implementing agencies. 
(iii)  Review policies and strategies (national and provincial Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 
Provincial Education Strategies 2020, and other related documents), particularly 
policies  on  education,  labor,  agriculture,  energy,  manufacturing,  and  service 
sectors. 
(iv)  Review and assess the current structure and function of VEGs and their potential 
for improving (a) skills training (training programs and curricula development, 
practical  training,  and  development  of  training  teams);  (b)  production  and 
technical  services  provided  by  schools;  (c)  research  and  development  of 
production technology; and (d) provision of technical services (skills training and 
upgrading  of  employees’  skills,  skills  assessment,  and  certification).  This 
assessment will include the current status of various forms of school–enterprise 
partnerships in TVET, with special attention to analyzing the division of labor 
among  government,  schools,  enterprises,  and  industry  associations. 
Recommendations for improving the structure and functions of VEGs, based on 
best international and national practices, will also be developed. 
(v)  Recommend  innovative  measures,  working  closely  with  other  consultants,  in 
relation to  legal  provisions to  improve  VEGs  (school–enterprise  and  school–
school partnerships) that are locally feasible. 
(vi)  Analyze and make recommendations  on improving competency standards of 
selected occupations for developing a qualification framework. 
(vii)  Analyze  and  make  recommendations,  working  closely  with  four  sector

and its projection for four selected sectors. 
(viii)  Develop a curriculum framework, curriculum, and guidelines for one subject in 
each of the four priority sectors for implementation, working closely with TVET 
academic specialists. 
(ix)  Develop  an  incentive  scheme  for  the  participation  of  enterprises  in  VEGs,

(x)  Supervise,  monitor,  and  participate  in  workshops,  including  training  of

(xi)  Ensure that qualitative research methods are applied in the survey from the

(xii)  Ensure a gender-responsive and culturally sensitive approach for all activities

B.  Technical  and  Vocational  Education  and  Training  Curriculum,  Standards,  and 
Qualifications Specialist (national, 7 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultant should have at least 7 years of hands-on experience developing TVET 
curricula. Having work experiences in school–enterprise partnerships for TVET development is 
preferred. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Conduct a comprehensive assessment of academic, institutional, administrative, 
and financial aspects of the TVET schools in Shaanxi, and identify constraints 
and  opportunities  for  improvement  through  stronger  school–enterprise 
cooperation. The consultant will (a) review and assess current curricula, courses, 
and teaching methods in classrooms; (b) assess the learning environment (e.g., 
school premises and practical workshops established at schools); (c) assess

students’  learning  materials  and  teachers’  reference  materials;  (d)  assess 
teachers’  qualifications,  capacity,  and  opportunities  for  teacher  training;  (e) 
assess the school system and support for students’ employment, such as career 
counseling services; (f) assess the cost of running schools in terms of school–
enterprise cooperation; and (g) assess the status of teacher training and school 
management.  
(ii)  Assess the current situation of VEGs and school–enterprise cooperation with 
regard to skills training (training programs and curricula development, practical 
training, and development of training teams), production and technical services 
provided by schools, research and development of production technology, and 
provision of technical services (skills training and upgrading of employees’ skills, 
skills assessment, and certification). 
(iii)  Analyze strengthening school–school partnerships (especially developed schools 
with  less-developed  schools)  and  make  suggestions  to  VEGs  on  resource 
sharing and technical cooperation. 
(iv)  With the team leader and other consultants, develop a field survey plan that 
includes quantitative and qualitative methodologies.  
(v)  Train data collectors on the use of quantitative and qualitative approaches to field 
surveys. 
(vi)  Analyze  collected  data  to  develop  draft  reports,  and  validate  findings  and 
recommendations during the consultation workshops with stakeholders to make 
the reports feasible and locally relevant. 
(vii)  Ensure the use of gender analysis utilizing sex-disaggregated data (male and 
female teachers, male and female administrators, boys and girls) in the research 
tools, analysis, and recommendations in the reports. 
(viii)  Develop  and  recommend  a  skills  framework  involving  enterprises,  industrial 
associations, and schools. 
(ix)  Develop  a  general  curriculum  framework,  curriculum,  and  its  implementation 
guidelines for one subject in each of the four priority sectors, working with four 
sector specialists using field survey results and analysis of demand in the four 
sectors.  
(x)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  conceptualizing  and  making  recommendations  to 
improve competency standards of selected occupations for development of a 
qualifications framework. 
 
C.  Technical  and  Vocational  Education  and  Training  Curriculum,  Standards,  and 
Qualifications Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
 
8.  The  international  consultant  should  have  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  TVET 
development,  particularly  in  links  with  industry.  He  or  she  should  have  comprehensive 
knowledge of and work experience in TVET issues at the school level in the People’s Republic 
of China. Work experience in international and national TVET projects in the People’s Republic 
of China is preferred. The role of the consultant is to bring international technical expertise and 
provide advice and recommendations to the team leader and other consultants to develop TA 
outputs (a technical report and a policy note) that meet international standards. The specialist 
will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Develop (a) curricula, courses, and teaching methods in classrooms; (b) learning 
environments  (e.g.,  school  premises  and  practical  workshops  established  at 
schools) and students’ learning materials and teachers’ reference materials; (c) 
assess teachers’ qualifications, capacity, and opportunities for teacher training;

Appendix 3  11 
(d)  assess  schools’  system  and  support  for  students’  employment,  such  as 
career counseling services; (e) assess the cost of running schools in terms of 
school–enterprise cooperation; and (f) assess the status of teacher training. 
(ii)  Conduct a comprehensive assessment of academic, institutional, administrative, 
and financial aspects of the TVET schools in Shaanxi; and identify constraints 
and  opportunities  for  improvement  through  stronger  school–enterprise 
cooperation:  (a)  review  and  assess  current  curricula,  courses,  and  teaching 
methods  in  classrooms;  (b)  assess  the  learning  environment  (e.g.,  school 
premises and practical workshops established at schools); (c) assess students’ 
learning  materials  and  teachers’  reference  materials;  (d)  assess  teachers’ 
qualifications,  capacity,  and  opportunities  for  teacher  trainings;  (e)  assess 
schools’  system  and  support  for  students’  employment,  such  as  career 
counseling services; (f) assess the cost of running schools in terms of school–
enterprise cooperation; and (g) assess the status of teacher training and school 
managers. 
(iii)  Analyze  collected  data  to  develop  draft  reports,  and  validate  findings  and 
recommendations during consultation workshops with stakeholders to make the 
reports feasible and locally relevant. 
(iv)  Ensure the use of gender analysis utilizing sex-disaggregated data (male and 
female teachers, male and female administrators, boys and girls) in the research 
tools, analysis, and recommendations in the reports. 
(v)  Make  recommendations  to  the  team  leader  and  academic  specialist  in 
developing  the  curriculum  framework,  curriculum,  and  its  implementation 
guidelines  based  on  the  international  experiences  of  school–enterprise 
partnership. 
(vi)  Assist the team leader in making recommendations for improving competency 
standards of selected occupations in developing qualification frameworks (e.g., 
Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Sri Lanka models).1 
 
D.  Sector Economists (four sector economists—one for each for the agriculture, energy, 
manufacturing, and service sectors) (national, 12 person-months)2 
 
9.  The consultants should have at least 5 years of experience working in respective sectors 
with good knowledge of the provincial economy and sector-specific issues, including challenges 
and human resource needs. The consultants will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review  the  overall  provincial  economic  development  plan,  including  the 
provincial plan and the provincial government’s planned investments. 
(ii)  Conduct an economic and labor market analysis, and a skills development needs 
analysis and review (a) structure (category) and quantity of needs of skills in 
each  sector,  including  the  assessment  and  forecasting  of  skills  needs;  (b) 
expected inflow of migrant workers into urban areas; and (c) impact of rural–
urban development. 
(iii)  Analyze  labor  market  information  and  other  agencies’  education  and  labor 
market information in respective sectors.

(iv)  Determine  in  detail  the  skills gap  of TVET graduates (supply  and  demand), 
conduct  an  analysis  with  other  consultants,  and  develop  feasible 
recommendations to reflect curriculum development. 
(v)  Conduct an in-depth survey and analysis of existing VEGs in each sector; identify 
challenges  and  incentives  for  industrial  associations  and  public  and  private 
enterprises; and prepare policy and practical recommendations. 
(vi)  Review,  analyze,  and  prepare  recommendations  for  skills  mapping  of  each 
sector; identify priority occupations in each sector (possibly including levels and 
categorizations). 
(vii)  Review,  analyze,  and  prepare  recommendations  to  improve  competency 
standards of selected occupations in developing the qualifications framework, 
supporting the strong engagement of enterprises and industry associations. 
(viii)  Assist the team leader in developing a field research plan and tools. 
(ix)  Provide  inputs  on  relevant  sector-specific  information  and  trends  to  the 
econometric  specialist,  and  its  analysis  on  human  resource  requirements, 
general  occupations  with  available  standard  occupational  classifications,  and 
other related details for the development of locally feasible labor projection and 
its models. 
(x)  Incorporate gender analysis and recommendations in all reports, participate in 
workshops  and  conferences,  and  assist  in  performing  other  relevant 
responsibilities. 
 
E.  Econometrician (national, 1 person-month) 
 
10.  The consultant should have at least 5 years of work experience in labor-related statistics, 
and in developing and implementing a labor projection model. The consultant will perform the 
following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review current labor and occupational projections, methodologies, and tools; 
identify gaps in analyzing historical population, housing, and economic trends; 
and  incorporate  future  demographic  rates  and  employment  shift-share 
assumptions. 
(ii)  Make suggestions to improve locally feasible labor and occupational projection 
models for each of the four sectors, providing existing definitions of occupations 
with available classifications. Working with four sector economists, the consultant 
will  (a)  review  and  develop  the  cohort-component  model,  (b)  link  population 
dynamics to economic trends based on the assumption that patterns of migration 
in and out of the province are influenced by job availability, and (c) compute labor 
force participation rates in comparison with labor numbers and the number of 
jobs projected by the shift in the economic and industry model. 
(iii)  Consider factors, such as migration patterns, business relocation, emergence of 
new occupations, or industrial and scientific development.
